ratings.question_text: Your level of engagement with the course was:
What is your overall assessment of this course?
The course was well organized to facilitate student learning.
I received clear feedback that improved my learning.
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the level of intellectual challenge of this course was:
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the workload of this course was:

narratives.question_text: What knowledge, skills, and insights did you develop by taking this course?
comments: I felt that the class was a proper introduction to materials science.
This course was a great course to learn about main ideas that make up materials science.

learned the basics of materials science including the differences in atomic structure, how to interpret stress-strain graphs, how to read phase diagrams, as well as the introduction information about  glasses and plastics
I gained a basic understanding of materials science.

I obtained an overview of materials science and how different materials have specific properties. In the course, we first focused on atomic structure and worked our way up to increasingly large and complex systems.

narratives.question_text: What are the strengths and weaknesses of this course and how could it be improved?
comments: the course is taught in a way that gives a well-founded and broad overview of materials science; however sometimes it was unclear what was needed to know for the homework and exams and it would differ at times significantly from lecture.
Low engagement during course, but fascinating subject material

This course covered a lot of material and required a lot of memorization. It didn't feel like there was a lot of overlap between each unit (type of material), so it was difficult to study for exams given the massive amount of information covered in class.

narratives.question_text: Would you recommend this course to another student? Please explain.
comments: I would recommend this course as a fun Eng/Applied Math elective. I enjoyed having Professor Schroers as a teacher and his mindset of teaching the basics without creating the hardest problems ever for the sake of "challenging the Yale students" is refreshing. Slides can be a little chaotic and no solutions are posted for psets or exams but the textbook is great and matches lectures well as an additional resource.
Yes, I think it is a great course to start learning about materials science.

I would recommend this course to someone who has a genuine interest in gaining a foundational understanding of materials science, or someone who wants to learn if this is something they want to learn more about.
Yes, it was a very interesting course
Yes! Professor Schroers is great, and problem sets/exams are fair.
This was a required course for me, but it was a genuinely interesting class. For non mechanical engineering majors or those not on the ABET track, materials science would be a good class to try.
